<general_instructions>
Your name is MetaOSSAgent, part of the Meta Agents Research Environments. You are an expert assistant helping users with their tasks.

You are helpful, harmless, and honest in all interactions. You have great problem-solving capabilities and can adapt to various task types and user needs
You always prioritize accuracy and reliability in your responses.
</general_instructions>

<agent_instructions>
You are an expert assistant who solves tasks by reasoning step by step and calling tools via JSON.

You must always follow the cycle:
1. Thought: explain what you are thinking and why a tool is needed.
2. Action: output a JSON blob that calls exactly ONE tool, then end with <end_action>.
3. Observation: (will be provided by the system; you NEVER generate this).

=== FORMAT SPECIFICATION ===
Thought: [Your reasoning in plain text]

Action:
{
  "action": "tool_name",
  "action_input": {
    "parameter1": "value1",
    "parameter2": "value2"
  }
}<end_action>


=== THOUGHT RULES ===
- Always explain your reasoning in natural language before the Action.
- Never include tool call details inside the Thought, only in the Action.
- In ALL your thought traces, please always include a todo-list of the steps that you will need to take, are currently taking, and have already completed.
    - If an event (e.g. a tool call, notification, wait time, etc.) requires new tasks to be done, add them to the todo list IMMEDIATELY in the ensuing thought trace.
    - Format the todo list as a markdown list, using [ ] for the steps that are not yet completed, [-] for the steps that are currently being taken, and [x] for the steps that have already been completed.
    - Do NOT return until you are sure you have thoroughly completed all aspects of every todo list item, including any new items that you may need to add.

=== ACTION RULES ===
- Only ONE tool call per Action.
- Always return a valid JSON object (no Markdown, no extra text, no comments).
- Use real values, not placeholders.
- If a tool takes no input, pass an empty dictionary: {}.
- For booleans, use true/false in lowercase.
- Always end with <end_action> immediately after the JSON.
- When acting, be concise and to the point with your tool calls and actions. Do NOT be overly formal or verbose.
- Only include the necessary information in the action_input. Do NOT include any extra information that is not immediate relevant to the task at hand, including information sent to any outside recipients.
- **Be thorough.** It's OK to take multiple steps or try multiple different avenues or tool calls to complete a task, so long as you are sure you have thoroughly completed all aspects of every todo list item, including any new items that you may need to add. However, you should look for the **path of least resistance** at any point in time.
<good_examples>
    - Checking every single email in an inbox in 3 tool calls
    - Listing all items in a shopping cart when a specific search fails
</good_examples>
<bad_examples>
    - Returning early after a single email query
    - Returning with a fail after a single specific search
</bad_examples>
- Do NOT compress multiple tool calls into one step or make duplicate unnecessary tool calls. Make exactly one tool call per Action you think is necessary.
- When making tool calls, always analyse your conversation history and the <relevant_multiagent_context> for relevant context or information (such as IDs or names). Do NOT make tool calls that duplicate fetches for unnecessary information.

<proactivity_guidelines>
You are allowed to be proactive, but only when the user asks you to do something. You should strive to strike a balance between:
- Doing the right thing when asked, including taking actions and follow-up actions
- Not surprising the user with actions you take without asking; specifically, do not make tool calls that are not explicitly asked for by the user.
</proactivity_guidelines>

=== OBSERVATION RULES ===
- Do NOT generate Observation; the system will insert it.


=== EXAMPLE CYCLE (for reference) ===
Thought: I need to look up the current weather before answering, so I will call the weather tool with the city name.

Action:
{
  "action": "get_weather",
  "action_input": {
    "city": "Paris"
  }
}<end_action>

Observation: The current temperature in Paris is 20 degrees Celsius and the weather is sunny.

============================


</agent_instructions>

<environment_instructions>

Should be used to end your turn and return any final output to the user. Returns: str | None
    Takes inputs: {'content': {'description': 'the content to send to the user', 'type': 'string', 'default': ''}}
    Returns an output of type: any

- SystemApp__get_current_time: Acts on app SystemApp: Get the current time, date and weekday, returned in a dict, timestamp as float (epoch), datetime as string (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS), weekday as string (Monday, Tuesday, etc.). Returns: dict
    Takes inputs: {}
    Returns an output of type: any

- SystemApp__wait_for_notification: Acts on app SystemApp: Wait for a specified amount of time or until the next external environment notification or user message is received, whichever comes first.
NOTE: this is the ONLY way to wait for notifications from the external environment. Do NOT use any other method or any manual checks to wait for notifications.
This method should only be used when there are no other tasks to perform or when explicitly instructed to monitor or wait. Returns: NoneType
    Takes inputs: {'timeout': {'description': 'The maximum amount of time to wait in seconds. If a notification is received before this time elapses, the wait will end early.', 'type': 'integer', 'default': 0}}
    Returns an output of type: any

- final_answer: Provides a final answer to the given problem. MUST be called in accordance with the formatting specification in the thought-action format
    Takes inputs: {'answer': {'type': 'any', 'description': 'The final answer to the problem'}}
    Returns an output of type: any

FUNDAMENTAL RULES FOR TASK EXECUTION:
1. COMMUNICATION: Only message the user when completely done or if the task is impossible.
2. EXECUTION: Work silently, complete tasks fully, no progress updates.
3. COMPLIANCE: Follow user instructions exactly, ask for clarification only if the environment does not provide enough information.
4. PROBLEM SOLVING: Try alternative approaches before reporting failure.
5. INFORMATION: Use available tools to gather missing information before asking user.
6. AMBIGUITY: Execute all clear and unambiguous parts of a request immediately. When you encounter ambiguities, contradictions, or impossible elements, finish unambiguous subtasks and then stop and explicitly ask the user for clarification before proceeding with those specific parts.




        You operate within the context of a larger external environment, and are able, as the orchestrator, to interact with that external environment through the SystemApp. Make tool calls that give you the best chance to **thoroughly** and **efficiently** accomplish the task at hand.
        **IMPORTANT:** NEVER delegate or mention any environment-related instructions, such as monitoring, waiting, time passage, etc. to ANY expert agents. You **alone** have the ability to interact with the external environment, **even if** it falls within the domain of an expert agent.
Example: If the task is to monitor a certain process for a period of time, you should use the SystemApp tools in order to wait for further notifications within that period of time.

      Notification policy:
      - All new messages from the User will be notified to you.
      - The environment state may also change over time, but environment events will not be notified to you. Once waiting time has concluded, you MUST check:
        1. The **current time** by calling the SystemApp__get_current_time tool IMMEDIATELY
        2. Your todo list in previous traces to find remaining tasks to complete
        3. Relevant queries and apps that you had tasks in previous to the wait call; these should be checked PROACTIVELY with the relevant tool calls
        4. Relevant notifications from the NotificationSystem
      - Whenever necessary, proactively check for any other update in an App by using the tools given to you. 
        - Waiting MUST be done through the SystemApp tools as necessary, not by repeatedly checking or manually monitoring based on the current time.
        - Subagents **CANNOT** do this, and they will fail if you delegate a `monitor` or `wait` task to them.
        - After waiting, ALWAYS check the **current time** first. Also check for relevant updates in any apps that were affected by the waiting. Do NOT return until you are sure you have thoroughly completed all aspects of the task at hand.

You are an orchestrator agent. Your role is to coordinate and delegate tasks to specialized expert agents. You have access to expert agents for each application. Use the expert agent tools to delegate tasks efficiently and concisely when appropriate. Ensure all provided instructions are minimal, and do not include any unnecessary details that are outisde of the scope of the subagent's capabilities. Do NOT give more qualifiers or conditions until misalignment is explicitly detected in <relevant_multiagent_context> to maintain efficiency. The expert agents are to be considered junior interns. They can only handle a single condition or qualifier at each time when handling the detailed work with their respective applications.

<misalignment_and_redelegate_guidance>
- If you detect misalignment with the user instruction, such as a subagent incorrectly reasoning on existing information, calling the wrong tool, or using the wrong arguments, **immediately REDELEGATE** with more explicit instructions, naming tools, arguments, and conditions (what the subagent SHOULD and SHOULD NOT do).

<misalignment_examples>
- Subagent chooses a more expensive option when the cheapest option is requested.
- Subagent incorrectly uses the wrong arguments by calling the tool `list_rides` with the wrong start_location/end_location.
- Subagent incorrectly uses the wrong arguments by calling the tool `order_ride` with the wrong service_type.
- Subagent incorrectly calls a tool when not requested or when not relevant to the task at hand.
</misalignment_examples>
</misalignment_and_redelegate_guidance>

[TASK]: 
Received at: 2024-10-15 07:00:00
Sender: User
Message: I need to move out, but my budget is tight at the moment. Delete all properties in Stockholm from my saved apartments list that are not in the 1000-1800 price range. Save all unsaved properties in Stockholm within that price range to my list. If any properties matching my criteria are listed within 4 minutes from now, immediately send a Messages to my friend Linnea Svensson each time a new property within their budget is listed, as she is also looking to move out. Don't notify me, I'll check my list later.
Already read: True
Read at: 2024-10-15 07:00:00

Thought: The user requests to manage their saved apartments list specific to Stockholm: remove apartments outside the 1000-1800 price range, add unsaved apartments within that range, and monitor for new listings within 4 minutes to notify a friend but not the user.

Steps:
- Remove saved apartments in Stockholm outside the 1000-1800 price range.
- Add unsaved apartments in Stockholm within the price range to the saved list.
- Monitor for 4 minutes for new apartments in Stockholm within the price range.
- For each new match during that time, send a message to Linnea Svensson and not to the user.

First, I will start with the deletion and addition of properties in the user's saved list.

Action:
{
  "action": "RentAFlat__expert_agent",
  "action_input": {
    "task": "In Stockholm, delete all saved apartments outside the 1000-1800 price range. Then save all unsaved apartments within the 1000-1800 price range to the user's saved apartments list."
  }
}

[OUTPUT OF STEP 1] Observation:
***
All saved apartments in Stockholm outside the 1000-1800 price range have been removed, and all unsaved apartments within this price range have been saved successfully.
***

I was not able to send emails to the participants because I do not have access to an email tool. You may need to call another tool in order to complete this part of the task.'
